sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea: 100 mg ORALLY 2 times daily; discontinue therapy in patients who have severe constipation for more than 4 days
  • Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea: 75 mg ORALLY 2 times daily in patients who do not have a gallbladder; discontinue therapy in patients who have severe constipation for more than 4 days

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Hepatic impairment, mild (Child-Pugh class A) or moderate (Child-Pugh class B): Reduce to 75 mg orally 2 times daily
  • Hepatic impairment, severe (Child-Pugh class C): Contraindicated
  • Concomitant use with OATP1B1 inhibitors: Reduce to 75 mg orally 2 times daily
  • Cannot tolerate 100 mg dose: Reduce to 75 mg orally 2 times daily

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Alcoholism, alcohol abuse, alcohol addiction, or consumption of more than 3 alcoholic drinks daily
  • Biliary duct obstruction, known or suspected
  • Chronic or severe constipation, history of or sequelae from constipation
  • Hepatic impairment, severe
  • Mechanical gastrointestinal obstruction, known or suspected
  • Pancreatitis, history of
  • Sphincter of Oddi disease or dysfunction
  • Structural disease of pancreas (ie, known or suspected pancreatic duct obstruction)

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- Pancreatitis, not associated with sphincter of Oddi spasm, may occur; monitoring recommended; discontinue use if symptoms suggestive of pancreatitis occur; may resolve upon discontinuation
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Increased risk of sphincter of Oddi spasm possibly resulting in pancreatitis or hepatic enzyme elevations; discontinue use if symptoms occur and do not restart if biliary duct obstruction or sphincter of Oddi spasm have developed during use
  • -- Absence of gallbladder increases risk for sphincter of Oddi spasm; consider alternative therapies or if used, monitor for symptoms
  • -- Hepatic impairment; dose adjustment and monitoring recommended
  • Concomitant use:
  • -- Avoid chronic or excessive alcohol use
  • -- Avoid use with drugs (eg, alosetron, anticholinergics, opioids) that may lead to constipation; loperamide may be used occasionally for acute diarrhea

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Dermatitis, Rash, Urticaria
  • Gastrointestinal:Flatulence (3%), Nausea (7% to 8%), Swollen abdomen (3%), Viral gastroenteritis (1% to 3%), Vomiting (4%)
  • Hepatic:ALT/SGPT level raised (2% to 3%), AST/SGOT level raised (2% or less)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (3%), Sedated (2% or less), Somnolence (2% or less)
  • Psychiatric:Euphoria (2% or less)
  • Respiratory:Asthma (2% or less), Bronchitis (3%), Bronchospasm (2% or less), Nasopharyngitis (3% to 4%), Upper respiratory infection (3% to 5%)
  • Other:Feeling intoxicated (2% or less), Nasopharyngitis (2% to 3%)
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (6% to 7%), Constipation (7% to 8%), Pancreatitis (0.2% to 0.3%), Spasm of sphincter of Oddi (0.2% to 0.8%)
  • Respiratory:Respiratory failure (2% or less)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Eluxadoline has agonist activity at the mu- and kappa-opioid receptors and antagonist activity at the delta-opioid receptor. Interaction with opioid receptors occurs in the gut.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: 1.5 hours (fed); 2 hours (fasting)
  • Effects of food: Cmax decreased 50%, AUC decreased 60% with high-fat meal

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Site of metabolism: unknown
  • Substrate of OATP1B1
  • Inhibitor of OATP1B1 and BCRP

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• Signs of sphincter of Oddi spasm, in patients without a gallbladder (eg, elevated liver enzymes); especially during the first few weeks of treatment
  • Symptoms of sphincter of Oddi spasm, in patients without a gallbladder (eg, abdominal pain or pancreatitis); especially during the first few weeks of treatment
  • New or worsening abdominal pain that may spread to the back or shoulder and may occur with or without nausea and vomiting
  • Impaired mental or physical abilities necessary to perform potentially hazardous activities (eg, driving, operating machinery), in patients with hepatic impairment

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report symptoms of sphincter of Oddi spasm or pancreatitis.
  • Instruct patient to report severe constipation.
  • Side effects may include nausea, abdominal pain or distension, vomiting, upper respiratory tract infection, nasopharyngitis, bronchitis, dizziness, or rash.
  • Encourage patient to take drug with food.
  • Tell patient to avoid chronic or acute excessive alcohol use due to increased risk of pancreatitis.
  • Advise patient to skip a missed dose and continue with the regular dosing schedule.
